figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Málaga
figure.label: AT. MALAGA C: Camera Lucida

div.ab: time we came to olives & a burning red soil the mountains very steep sometimes covered with vines in terraces, sometimes with broom. A clear River ran on the right the road made with care & very good, sometimes conducted zigzag up a rocky point to avoid the circuit of a very long peninsular Mt Mountains . Stop to water our horses at a VentaCountry inn where is an oil mill. Prickly fig hedges & aloes. A monastery with cypresses and oranges. At length in a broiling day Dec 1 come in sight of the plain of Malaga, bare but cultivated, with farm houses but no trees Better about the town, the descent becomes less rapid half a league from the city. Pass a Monastery with a fine walled grove of oranges & lemons R. right See a fine Casa de Campocountry house & oranges L left once belonging to the Jesuits. At Malaga the climate Dec 1. 2. 3. & 4 quite delightful, much too hot in the sun & the nights not cold. In the sun the Thermometer rose immediately to 95 & in the coldest situations was about 65 Dec 4. Green Pease cauliflowers &.. plentiful. Almost all the walls built by the moors. but not now walled round. A good moorish gate near the Alameyda or parade. Fine cathedral & organ. the port made by a natural projection & a pier. The sea & sky equally serene. The Thermometer from 70 to 76 & 78 from Decr 1 to 20 & only one cold wind during that time from N.W. north-west The number
div.note: The venta de GalvesGálvez country inn a large inn on the road close on R

In 1364 when Kg Don Pedro held his court at Sevilla “mandò facer estas alcaçares e estos palacios e estas portadas que fue hecho en la era de mil e quatrocientos e dos” He ordered these fortresses and these palaces and these façades to be made, which were finished around [in the era of] 1402 WG seems to have corrected Llaguno y Amírola's 'fecho' to 'hecho'.Inscription on frize. This by Arab architects

The sala llamada de Embajadores del mismo alcazarThe hall known as that of the Ambassadors in the same fortress.. But Jalubi of Toledo first built the palace as says inscripn in Arabic. “Jalubi fue el arquitecto di mi obra y maestro mayor. Fue venido de Toledo con los demas maestros Toledanos a mi palacio y maestranza de Sevilla. Yo el Rey Nazar por la gracia de Dios.Jalubi was the architect of my work and chief master. He had come from Toledo with the other Toledan masters to my palace and armoury of Seville. I, King Nazar, by the grace of God.

Two inscriptions possibly taken from Eugenio Llaguno y Amírola, Noticias de los arquitectos y arquitectura de España..., 4 vols (Madrid: Imprenta Real, 1829), vol. 1, pp. 66, 238. Idiosyncratic spellings (e.g. 'e' rather than 'y' where not necessary) match. Would also fit with WG's more cramped hand, which he tends to use in notes datable to 1820s-30s, and fact that text is squashed around existing sketches. Clear elsewhere that WG used Llaguno y Amírola.
Sidi Achmet Elegacel Ambassador from Morocco to Carlos III translated Arabic inscriptions in SpainLlaguno y Amírola, Noticias, p. 238, n. 1.
Duquesa deDuchess of Gor’s Coachman who drove us up to the Alhambra with 4 horses, only two of which had reins She called him Mi hijomy son.
